choices.E: The @Controller annotation is a stereotype annotation like @Component.
choices.B: The classes are eligible for handling requests in Spring MVC.
choices.C: The classes must be annotated together with @EnableMvcMappings to be discovered via component scanning.
choices.A: The @Controller annotated classes can only render views.
choices.D: @Controller is interchangeable with @RestController with no extra code changes for the methods inside the class.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about @Controller annotated classes? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Correct answer is ABF. Locale - represent use's local such as language or country
Principal - represent currently logged/authenticated user
HttpSession - represent user's current HTTP Session

so request and Session are too general thus why they're not correct and Language is part of Locale, and spring does not know language but locale.
A, B , F , Locale specify what session users want (depends on location or language) , httpSession is the session we use for client and server, and principal is user authentication

questions.question_text: Which three types can be used as @Controller method arguments? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
The two options that are REST principles are:
A. RESTful applications use a stateless architecture.
This means that the server does not keep any client state between requests. Each request from the client to the server must contain all the information needed to understand and process the request.

B. RESTful application use HTTP headers and status codes as a contract with the clients.
HTTP headers and status codes are used to communicate the status of the request, any errors that occurred, and metadata about the returned resource. This is part of the uniform interface constraint of REST. 

Options C, D, and E are not principles of REST. RESTful applications can use caching (option C is incorrect), do not keep track of client state (option D is incorrect), and favor loose coupling between clients and servers (option E is incorrect).

questions.question_text: Which two options are REST principles? (Choose two.)

choices.D: RESTful application servers keep track of the client state.
choices.E: RESTful applications favor tight coupling between the clients and the servers.
choices.B: RESTful application use HTTP headers and status codes as a contract with the clients.
choices.A: RESTful applications use a stateless architecture.

questions.question_text: Which three statements are advantages of using Springâ€™s Dependency Injection? (Choose three.)

choices.D: Configuration can be externalized and centralized in a small set of files.
choices.E: Dependency injection creates tight coupling between components.
choices.C: Dependencies between application components can be managed external to the components.
choices.F: Dependency injection facilitates loose coupling between components.
choices.A: Dependency injection can make code easier to trace because it couples behavior with construction.
choices.B: Dependency injection reduces the start-up time of an application.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CDF
I think C, D and F are the best answer
why A and C are wrong ?

comments.content: A. is incorrect. Dependency Injection decouples behavior from construction, making it easier to manage and test components independently.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are correct when @SpringBootApplication is annotated on a class? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Correct answer is AB. A reason why E is not a valid answer is because in typical Apring boot application, there will only be one ApplicationContext created however you can have multiple but this will lead to complication and unexpected behaviour to happen.

Selected Answer: AB
A and B

Selected Answer: AB
These are correct

choices.B: Component scanning will start from the package of the class.
choices.D: Methods in the class annotated with @Bean will be ignored.
choices.A: It causes Spring Boot to enable auto-configuration by default.
choices.C: All other annotations on the class will be ignored.
choices.E: A separate ApplicationContext will be created for each class annotated with @SpringBootApplication.
